segments.text: Well, Roger Revell came out to Pearl Harbor and he couldn't buy any shoes because he wore a 14 size and his toes were flapping out.
Unfortunately, he got a case of cold one day and had to go to bed so I could get his shoes sewed up.
And during those two hours while he was in bed and I was waiting for the shoes, he talked to me about oceanography.
Were you in the Navy then?
But actually, it goes much further back than that.
My father's people are from the coast of St. Simons, Georgia.
And I always wanted to get to the coast, with my mother being an artist like the mountains.
So I was trying to get to the coast.
And finally, when I went into the Navy as an enlisted man, I was thrown out for being colorblind.
After a month in the dispensary, the chief showed me a manual of a thing called a bathy thermograph.
He said, well, you know a little bit about sonar.
Why don't you go up to Woods Hole?
Maybe they'll give you a better job.
August 23rd, 1941 was an awful hot day.
The Atlantis was getting ready to go on a cruise.
I sent my regards to the South Carolina Power Company and started in as a technician on Ewing's project up there.
Then I went into the Navy, as the tape tells, as the BT tape tells, and rode herd on the Bath and Thermograph boys.
all through Bikini.
At the end of that time, probably really urged on by Roger Revelle and another talk I'd had with Ray Montgomery, I took the GI Bill of Rights and went to Scripps, and they let me in under the door.
What was Maurice Ewing like?
If you haven't read the November 4, 11, and 18 New Yorker of 1974 profiles,
you have missed a gem of a description of the explosion of oceanography and the earth sciences largely due to this great genius.
Morris Ewing was the most, he was a genius.
One of the few I ever met.
He could be as homely as an old shoe, tell you a joke right out of the Big Bend area or any part of Texas.
But at the same time, when it came to knowing what he wanted to do, he had the gift.
of making the right choice.
I'll never forget a lesson.
On an Atlantis cruise, we went across one of the canyons.
I thought I'd noticed a change in the temperature structure.
While I was sitting there thinking about it, of course, we were miles down the road.
Ewing came to me and said, King, next time you get in an occasion like that, don't think
Just take the data.
Take more and more and more and more as fast as you can and figure it out afterwards.
A lesson I never forgot.
I once asked him, how do you know how to start a project?
What is the most important thing?
How do you pick it out?
And he said, well, King, if the time ever comes when I think it's necessary to my project to count the rivets on the Atlantis deck, I'll count the rivets on the Atlantis deck.
But therein lay his genius and that intuitive...
choice of the main aim.
And he never was looking just at the day, as you know, with the seismographs on the moon and all that.
He was always way ahead of his time.
And I think one of the most engaging things about him was his common real delight in the discoveries that were being made.
It was my good fortune to spend one night there with him, Joe Warzel,
John Ewing and his wife at Lamont's, at the house there, Ewing and Lamont.
We just sat around and talked about things.
And he'd say things like this.
He said, well, I don't know if we want to change this or that.
You know, we've got a ship now.
And if something interesting is happening, we can send somebody there to look at it.
Just the commonplace, common sense approach to everything that he did.
He has, as the New York article brings out so well, he was fundamentally a teacher.
That was his dream, that was his love.
The story is told, perhaps part from the time he was, I believe, with, was it Lehigh?
That someone said, you're flunking too many of your students.
He said, well, suppose I could get an outstanding PhD for each year.
for this university that I teach.
Oh, that would be wonderful, they said.
He said, all right.
I'm going to talk then at the level of the best student I have in the class.
And the rest of them, if you don't mind, I'll just throw the books down the stairs and grade them according to where they land.
Of course, he wasn't that trash.
But as a teacher, as a person able to explain a thing in simple terms, and that enthusiasm, they brought in the first
from Africa, off the African coast, the first records.
I was at Lamont one day when they came in by special courier.
They spread them out on the table and John and Bruce, who they were very friendly at that time, and Ewing went bemused from record to record.
Hazel would say, yes,
I found it a thousand miles northeast of there, so here it is here again.

And Ewing showed me his own sketch and plot of the distribution of manganese nodules from Panama to Hawaii as it came in from all the data that they had, and he'd already come to the conclusion of how they increased with distance and along that course.
He was always overworked, always tired, but always...
approachable.
He'd come to Washington, didn't wear a hat.
You'd see his hair above all the crowd, admirals and others on the streets in those days.
He'd walk in with that calm smile, and he'd take us all to the Cosmos Club, and when the cupids on the ceiling began to dance, we knew we'd had enough to drink.
Now, you were in Woods Hole?
Yes, that's where I first met him.
And he was, at that time,
They had built about 15 bathy thermographs in the shop, and they were beginning to survey the...
They had the idea of putting them on ships and surveying the waters of the North Atlantic.
Then the war broke out right in the middle of that program.
But he was already there in 1940, early 41.
And there's a very, very important report of Woods Hole called...
underwater sound in seawater that came out and reprinted in 42 that should be a part of this record.
I once asked him where he got the basic sound velocity data calibrations.
He showed me a Navy notebook in which there must have been 500 handwritten calculations based on the temperatures that he'd found.
And he said, here's where I established it.
I was always trying to make him do something about sound velocity in the sea after those days.
I said, when are you going to make it more precise?
He said, when I find it in the affairs of my work.
Of course, his development with Luskin, he was really head of the project, but Luskin did the work with the manufacturers.
The precision depth recorder was a milestone in getting the precision of timing it to 1.2 million
which was unheard of in those days, and took out the variability due to the swing of the ship's generator and the sound velocity, and therefore the distance measurements to the bottom.
Did you stay at Woods Hole until 1945?
No, I was at Woods Hole for eight months from 1943, August 1941, to February 1942,
They gave me a wave on my eyes and took me back in the Navy as a junior grade lieutenant, the fastest promotion in history.
And what were your duties in the Navy?
During the first eight months at the Bureau of Ships, I rode herds on the manufacture of bathy thermographs with the big contractors like the Waterbury and the Submarine Signal Company.
It was purely administrative work on contracts.
And as I've said elsewhere, the important fact in this case is
that the bathy thermograph was considered by the Navy a component of sonar equipment and therefore was never under the restriction of just scientific instruments.
It was bought as a device.
And that's the way Morris Ewing looked at it too.
He did not look at it as a precision instrument.
And all the money that's been spent on trying to make a bathy thermograph record accurately, quote unquote, has always amused me because what he wanted was a relative profile, the relative changes,
those breaks in the trace which indicated where the things were, rather than the exact temperature at a given spot in time as you get with a reversion thermometer or something of that kind.
Did you know Athelston Spellhouse?
Yes, he was, I knew him later in Washington, and of course I was at his original Sea Grant dissertation up in Rhode Island when he launched that program.
But I met him, and the bathy thermograph paper of Lafon's and mine
are based on papers and stories I got from him personally.
Was it your impression he ever approached the idea of the BT being an exact measuring device?
No, I don't think so.
When you were with the Bureau of Ships, what other contacts did you have there to guide your career later in life?
Well, of course, when I went out to the Pacific, Roger Revelle was just coming in.
In fact, I met him in Los Angeles for the first time when he was coming into Washington.
His main interest was where he could get a hotel room.
But he and Dick Fleming met me in Los Angeles.
And then when he took over, as I've tried to describe on the other tape,
It was perhaps one of the most important signal moves and fortunate coincidences in the history of oceanography.
Okay.

What I'm interested in very much in here now, knowing that when the moves were made to create the Office of ONR with the Bureau of Ships and the Hydrographic Office, how do you remember that role as Navy is going to be placed into oceanographic research?
Well, I think it became, if you'll talk to Jim Wakelin on this, and Arthur Maxwell, and Gordon Lill, you will get the exact information.
I think it came out of the fact that people like Wakelin, who were on duty in the Navy, realized that there should be an assistant secretary for R&D, and out of that whole impetus,
came the Office of Naval Research.

I have never read a history of its formation, but I do know how the money changed from the Bureau of Ships over to the ONR more and more and more as ONR grew in stature and could take over more and more of the basic research support.
At the beginning of Bikini, as Roger went out to Bikini,
He met me for one night between 11 o'clock and 5 the next morning at Pearl Harbor.
I was going back in to sit on his defunct desk, and he urged that I get three contracts signed, one with Scripps, one with Woods Hole, and one with, I believe it was Lamont at that time.
And the Bureau of Ships was still funding, doing the major funding of those that early.
Now, ONR came on.
about, what was it, 46, 47?
And from then on, everything gravitated.
The Bureau, of course, was really a little out of its field.
More has been hung on the necessity for knowing about the ocean for sonar than any other reason that you can think of.
And it was Roger's own task description that...
lasted for about 15 years, about seven sentences, that created the basis for the funding of a great deal of oceanographic work in the Navy.
Now, but you went out to Bikini with Rebell, didn't you?
He caught me.
I got on a tanker and had gone down to Bikini and had just gotten there.
I was halfway down there when the captain called me and said, what have you done, run off with some money or something?
I said, no, they said they want you to go back to Washington immediately.
So I saw Bikini from the air as they sent me back by seaplane to Pearl Harbor.
I never set foot on it.
You didn't see the explosion of the devices themselves?
No, I missed all the big...
I blamed somebody for that, and I looked for that jerk for ten years, and finally I found a letter I had written saying I'd sit anywhere they wanted me.
Okay, when you come back then, your next job is administrative in terms of, I thought, the hydrographic office.
Is that wrong?
In the fall of 1946, I went out to Scripps in advance because I was really not out of the Navy until November.
And thanks to Walter Monk coaching me on the math and the help of the other students out there, I was able to get a master's degree under the GI Bill of Rights, graduating in 1948.
John Cochran and I got our degrees along with Woody Jacobs getting his doctorate up at UCLA that hot June day.
I went in in July and Dick Fleming gave me a job at the Hydrographic Office for the first two or three years.
I can never remember offhand whether I left the, I think I left it on January the 2nd, 1951.
At the Hydrographic Office, I was in charge of oceanic development and had a part

in the developing of the instrumentation for the two first seagoing vessels as oceanographic vessels, the San Pablo and the Rehoboth, vessels which Tommy Austin took to sea and did so well with in establishing the traditions and beginning of the oceanographic cruises of which there have been so many since.
I didn't fit in too well at the Hydrographic Office.
I was more used to the Bureau of Ships, and when I was able to get a job over there, I transferred.
And they put me in charge of these same contracts that had been running with the Bureau since the war days under Dick Williams and George Cummings.
George Cummings, incidentally, lives in Port Charlotte.
And you should get in touch with him as he was Ross and Bennett's number two assistant and can give you much of the administrative information you wish.
He's still alive.
What did you not like about the Hydrographic Office?
Why?
I'd rather not go into that.
It was about that time I fell in love with a gallon.
It didn't turn out too well, so there were several things of that kind.
I don't blame anybody.
And how long did you stay with the Bureau of Ships?
From 1952, 51 if that's the date, until January 10, 1972.
And did you see any sizable change in the direction of the Bureau of Ships those 20 years?
Oh, yes.
Immediately after the war, when I came back there on the McKinney, this, as described in the manual there, this great organization had been cut down.

So far cut down, George Cummings and one lieutenant commander sat in a room at the end of a long corridor along which there were about 10 desks, and there was just one man left of each of the division's
An important group of that was the sonar analysis group.
And Frank Andres, whose name I've given you and address I've given you, can give you the background on that.
John Coleman of the Academy at one time was head of that group during the war.
And they played an important part in their requirements for information, which was oceanographically oriented.
The whole thing always was the bureau ships was a hardware outfit.
And it was quite difficult often to make far-out research without an absolute piece of hardware at the end of it go.

But people were generous and they were, by using the government, my one good thing, I think, was that I did use the government laboratories to the maximum in establishing good oceanographic programs in them in addition to the
university laboratories, and there's always competition.
ONR went the university route they should, but it was my great, well, the program was a success, was to get oceanography into about eight government laboratories.
Did you feel as if that, possibly after World War II, that the agency
with ONR and NSL and with bureauships and hydrographic office diversified oceanographic research too much?
Well, since I got most of my money from ONR into the Bureau, I always thought ONR was the daddy and the correct one.
I thought that there may have been

The most interesting thing, a division which even comes to this day, as I understand it, due to this poor Pascagoula move, or whatever you call it, the Hydrographic Office resisted greatly anything known as research.

They were used to cutting and tried, proven by the Maury approach, or the practical approach, and although we fought to get the control for our own government laboratories of two oceanographic ships, it was a long time before we could do it.
the Navy felt that the Navy Hydrographic Office, as a long-term function of CNO, was the proper place for the operation of those ships.
So you have the dichotomy of survey and research.
Where does one begin and the other end?
Where does data gathering for understanding and then data gathering for a hypothesis, where do they merge?
I won't say friction, but there was stress between the Hydrographic Office's aims in some areas and the Office of Naval Research as I saw them.
Do you believe in the concept of directed research or pure research?
In other words, what role do you see a research agent attached to the Navy?
Should the Navy have more specialized or mission-oriented research?

Of course, from a funding point of view, the wonderful old thing that used to be the theory, I say in that tape that is in the contracts, I'm not sure it was ever written in the contract as I think about it, but there was this idea in the bureauships when a thing had to be procured and you had to design it, you could go as far back in the theory as necessary to make a good design.
And this meant eventually basic research.
Uh-huh.
The Office of Naval Research is the place for the main aim of basic research in the Navy on problems specified of what they see as Navy-oriented needs.
I always liked in my program to have a leeway of 20 or 30 percent on the man who was getting the information for the hardware to do basic research in addition to just the applied part.
And I got some pretty good ones.
Eric Baldwin and
was the first man to see the scattering layer and understand what it was like.
This ability to look over the fence a little bit rather than at the directed aim, I don't think you can keep people turned on if you give them an assigned job.
In other words, you think that much of the important research comes almost accidentally in the sense of the discoveries?
Like, for example, the deep scattering layer.
Well, about basic research versus directed research.
Directed research has its place, particularly where you have a deadline and design.
and a cash budget that you have to meet.
But there should be something more in so-called undirected research than just data gathering.
There should be the idea that you can get the theory better and you have some freedom of thought.
There are two kinds of research.
There's a commercial research in which you never risk a nickel unless you can see a six-cent prop.
This is, of course, the background that the Bureau of Ships used to act on and did act on to a large extent.
And the industry has to do that, too, because they have to make a profit or they don't do anything.
But the undirected basic research is like water coming up on a marsh.
It runs in all directions through the channels, but suddenly the whole level of the water is two feet higher.
And that's the only way I can picture it.
I do not think you can direct basic research.
How much dealing did you have with private enterprise while you were serving off and on as a civil servant with the military?
Well, of course, in the beginning, the bureauships had all the funding of the institutional work.
And that great institution, the Marine Physical Laboratory, was established by the Bureau of Ships to bridge this thing that you're talking about right here.
Admiral Cochrane did a remarkable thing.
He said, we can't tell you how much we're going to give you, but we're going to give you some of our budget each year.
That was the first time that this had ever been done by the Navy, as I understand.
And he said, we will have, and as a result, they had three California professors independently
of this whole project, paid by the University of California with status and everything else, tenure in the whole business.
Carl Eckert was the first director, Leonard Lieberman and Russell Raitt.

And they had a direct feed-in to the technician type of people, the applied people, who could then take that, put it into an instrument, improve an underwater sound bomb, or make a thing of that kind.
and a better hydrofoam or better transducer because they had this feed-in of the best mines which were untrammeled by the necessity of meeting a deadline or being directed.
And when that was taken away from the Bureau as being too basic, it just put one layer of administration before we could get the dope out of MPL into the Bureau because it had to go through and off.

Did you seem to think that the relationship between private enterprise and the military and the universities functioned reasonably well without a great deal of bureaucracy while you were at the Bureau of Ships?
It didn't function without a great deal of bureaucracy.
Just look at your coordinating committees.
No.
Yes, I think toward the end and in the last, in the 60s, certainly in the 60s, industry began to ride it.
for all it was worth.
And I think we got a lot of beautifully written proposals without necessarily the full expected output.
But I can't say that, really.
